syllabus:
Selective Readings in the Novels, Spring 2021

Professor Hsiu-ling Lin,

By appointment only through email: [hllinberkeley@yahoo.com.tw](mailto:hllinberkeley@yahoo.com.tw).

The aim of this fiction selection course is to provide a general survey of the representative works of fiction by some major British novelists in the Victorian and the early Modern periods. In addition to traditional discussion of characterization and plot, we will focus on the historical, social contexts of these works. For example, Elizabeth Gaskell\`s _North and South_, besides interweaving intriguing twisting plots of traditional romance, provides an acute social criticism of industrialization, class discrepancy, the discrepancy between mill owner and the workers, between the rich and the poor. We will also pay particular attention on the depiction of London in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, especially represented in the works by Elizabeth Gaskell, Jane Austen, Charles Dickens, Rudyard Kipling, and Joseph Conrad, among others.

We will also focus on the prominent themes of these periods, such as “industrialization,” “romance,” and “spy fiction.” We will first watch various film adaptations of, and then read selections from, these novels. 

Industrialization and Romance:

Elizabeth Gaskell, _North and South_,

Jane Austen, _Pride and Prejudice_,

\-----.  _Mansfield Park_,

Charles Dickens, _Our Mutual Friend_.

Spy Fiction:

Rudyard Kipling: _Kim_.

Joseph Conrad, _Secret Agent_

Ian Fleming, Selection from _007_.

Syllabus is subject to change, contingent upon the schedule.

Grading policy:

Class Participation: 20%

Attendance: 10%, 3 absences automatically resulting in failing the class.

Final paper: 70%, 5-8 pages long.  The paper should be written in English, If you are an English major, or English-native speaker; otherwise, you may choose to write your paper in Chinese.
